oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woman in colorful woven wrap garment, with ornamental hair braids, metal hoop earrings, and jewelry including cowrie shell necklace, holding an infant, signed Baldridge at lower right.

Artist and illustrator Cyrus Leroy Baldridge (1889-1977) attended the Chicago School of Illustration as a boy. He worked as an illustrator after graduation from the University of Chicago and served as a war correspondent during World War I. While in the American infantry, he contributed to the Stars and Stripes, Leslie's Weekly and Scribners. His first book "I Was There with the Yanks in France" was a collection of his wartime sketches. After his marriage to Caroline Singer, the two traveled in Africa, mostly along the west coast, during the mid to late 1920s, staying in native villages in order to glean an understanding of the homelands and customs of the ancestors of contemporary African Americans. W.W. Norton published their book, entitled "White Africans and Black," written by Singer and illustrated by Baldridge, in 1929. During his career, Baldridge illustrated books for African American authors and worked for Opportunity, the magazine of the Urban League. Chicago businessman Samuel Insull purchased the collection of sketches from Baldridge's African sojourn and donated them to Fisk University in 1931.
